comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The woman on the Bain photo is not the woman mentionned in the NYT articles above. The latter was the former Madeleine McKissick (or Madeline Mc Kisick) who was married to Pedar Sather Bruguiere in 1899 already (see The San Francisco call., September 30, 1899, Page 9 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1899-09-30/ed-... ,with photo) and married Lieut. Janney in 1908 (The San Francisco call., September 15, 1908, Page 1, Col. 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1908-09-15/ed-...). The Mrs. Bruguiere on the Bain photo was the former Marion Andrews and was Pedar S. Bruguiere's second wife. They had a son also named Pedar, but they divorced soon (in 1906, see The San Francisco call., July 18, 1906, Page 14, col. 5 „TWICE MARRIED BUT WILL TRY AGAIN“ chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1906-07-18/ed-...) . Then she had a short marriage to Stewart Denning, which was annulated and she took back her first husbands name (New-York tribune., August 30, 1912, Page 9, Col 5 „WIFE SUES DR. BRUGUIERE“ chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1912-08-30/ed-...) She „came from an entirely worthy but unknown Southern family without money“, was under thirty in 1919, and married Peter Cooper Hewitt in this year (her third husband, see extensive article in The Washington times., January 12, 1919, NATIONAL EDITION, The American Weekly, Image 21 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1919-01-12/ed-..., with photos). The Bain photograph shows Marion Andrews Denning Bruguiere with her son Pedar possibly in 1918 or 1919. Article with photos of the honeymoon after her marriage to Peter Cooper Hewitt in The Ogden standard., April 19, 1919, LAST EDITION - 3:30 P.M., Image 24 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1919-04-19/ed-... After the death of her third husband in 1921, she was wooed by the Persian Shah, refused him 17 times and married Baron Robert d'Erlanger, see The evening world., July 14, 1922, Wall Street Final Edition, Page 3, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1922-07-14/ed-..., with photos The Ogden standard-examiner., August 13, 1922, The Standard - Examiner Sunday Feature Section, Page 5, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058393/1922-08-13/ed-..., with photos
